articles.title: Tasks for day 1
articles.contents:
Contents
1 First document and text
1.1 Preparing the data
1.2 Create first rmarkdown document
1.2 Let’s add some text
2 Add R code
2.1 Load the palmerpenguins in your document
2.2 Add R code chunks
2.1 Add inline code
2.3 Chunk options

3 Change YAML header

1 First document and text
1.1 Preparing the data
To practice, we will write a short paper about a data set on 3 different penguin species (Chinstrap, Gentoo, and Adelie) on islands in Antarctica. As we progress in the workshop, we will incorporate more options, functionality and formatting into the document.
Artwork by Allison HorstThe data is available from the palmerpenguins package. To get it, you have to open RStudio and:
Install the package with install.packages("palmerpenguins")
Take a moment to get familiar with the data set and its variables:
Load the package into your R session with library(palmerpenguins) (just do this in the console)
Type penguins in the console and you should see the penguins tibble
It contains data on bill and flipper size, weight and sex of the 3 penguin species
We will need the data later, so remember that you can access via the variable penguins.
1.2 Create first rmarkdown document
For all tasks of today, you might find it helpful, to open the R Markdown cheat sheet for reference.
Start by creating a new .Rmd file:
Go to File -> New File -> R Markdown... and
Chose HTML as default output format from the Document section (This should be already selected as default)
If you want, you can already enter a title and author
Save the file in a convenient location on your machine.
Before you start working with the document:
Knit the document to see what happens
Try the Knit button on top of your document or the keyboard shortcut Ctrl/Cmd + Shift + K
Chose different output formats to knit to by clicking on the little black arrow next to the Knit button

1.2 Let’s add some text
Now start writing your very own paper about the 3 penguins.
First, remove all template text from the document except the YAML header and the first code chunk (we will learn later what that does).
Before you start writing, have a quick look at the Example text that I show below. It is the one we discussed together just now and includes many different markdown formatting elements and some text about the penguin data set.
You can find the links that I used in the text in the Links section or by right clicking on the text
Now write a text yourself. You can either reproduce my text and use copy paste to type less, or you can write your own text about penguins (or anything else you want to write about). The important thing in this task is to include many different markdown formatting elements.
During the writing process, don’t forget to knit your document often. It’s easier to fix mistakes and error messages if you detect them early.

Example text
The penguins of Antarctica
Selina Baldauf
25/03/2022
Introduction
There are three main penguin species in Antarctica (Chinstrap, Gentoo, Adelie). You can see them in the following figure:
Artwork by Allison HorstIn this paper we want to answer the following questions
How does bill depth depend on bill length?
Which penguin species has the highest body mass?
Methods
The data
The data was collected on islands in Antarctica and published by Gorman et al. (2014). You can find the original paper with the title “Ecological sexual dimorphism and environmental variability within a community of Antarctic penguins (genus Pygoscelis)” in PLoS ONE1
The data is published via the palmerpenguins R package which you can find on this website.
The data contains (among others) the following measurements:
bill length
bill depth
body mass
sex
male
female

The analysis
We did some plots, calculated some summary statistics and a linear model of the form \(y = ax + b + \epsilon\)
Results
Will be added later
Links used
Here are the links that I used in the text for URL links and the figure. You can use them to reproduce my text. But feel also free to link other things if you want.
Link to Allison Horst’s twitter: https://twitter.com/allison_horst
Link to the paper: https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0090081
Link to the palmerpenguins package: https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/
Link to the penguin image: https://github.com/allisonhorst/palmerpenguins/blob/master/man/figures/lter_penguins.png?raw=true


2 Add R code
2.1 Load the palmerpenguins in your document
We will now include some analysis of the penguins data in the document.
As with “normal” R code, you need to load the palmerpenguins package in your document in the beginning.
A convenient location to load packages is the setup code chunk.
Just add library(palmerpenguins) as a line in this chunk.
You can always come back to the setup chunk and add all the packages that you need in your analysis. Then you have all the library() calls in one place.
2.2 Add R code chunks
Now let’s add some R code that produces different types of output in the document.
First finish all the tasks and then come back to the extra (the linear model) if you still have time.
Try using both the RStudio interface (Code -> Insert Chunk) and the keyboard shortcut (Ctrl/Cmd + Alt/Option + I) to insert R code chunks.
The different output types we will try are:
A figure for the penguin data set
A summary table of the data set
A linear model with the data set (Extra)
For each of the output types, go through the following steps:
Select the location in your document, where you want the output to be (probably the result section).
Insert a new code chunk at the location
Write the code that produces the output (you can copy it from my examples below)
Run the code inside the document
Click on the little green arrow button next to the code chunk
Careful: if you get an error message, make sure that you run all chunks that your code depends on before. E.g. you probably have to run the setup chunk to load all the packages first.
Knit the document and see how the output looks like
Below, you find example code for a figure, a table and a linear model. I suggest, you copy my code to your R chunk. If you still have time, you can change the code or write new code.
Don’t forget
Every time, you use a function from a new package, you have to load the package into the document environment. Just add another library() line to the setup chunk.
Knit your document often to detect errors early on

Figure
I use ggplot2 to produce the figures, so don’t forget to load the package in the setup chunk.
Chose one of the two figure ideas from below:
Create a histogram of the body mass for the 3 penguin species


ggplot(penguins, aes(x = body_mass_g, fill = species)) +
  geom_histogram(alpha = 0.6) +
   scale_fill_manual(values = c("darkorange", "purple", "cyan4")) +
  theme_minimal()



Create a scatter plot of the relationship between bill length and bill depth


ggplot(
  data = penguins,
  aes(
    x = bill_length_mm,
    y = bill_depth_mm,
    color = species,
    shape = species
  )
) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("darkorange", "purple", "cyan4")) +
  theme_minimal()



Summary table
I create a summary table of the mean variable values grouped by penguin species and sex.
I use the dplyr package here, so don’t forget to load it in the setup chunk.


penguins %>% 
  filter(!(is.na(sex))) %>% 
  group_by(species, sex) %>% 
  summarize(
    bill_length = mean(bill_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE),
    bill_depth = mean(bill_depth_mm, na.rm = TRUE),
    flipper_length = mean(flipper_length_mm, na.rm = TRUE),
    body_mass = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE)
  )



Linear Model (Extra)
I create a linear model to test the effect of bill length on bill depth and to see if it differs between species.
Don’t worry if you don’t know exactly what a linear model is. This course is about markdown after all :)


# Calculate the linear model
lm_penguins <- lm(bill_depth_mm ~ bill_length_mm + species, data = penguins)
# Create the summary table
summary(lm_penguins)




2.1 Add inline code
Add some sentences to the document that use R code to report some numbers.
You can start with the ideas below. If you still have time in the end, you can add more sentences:
Report the mean body mass of all penguins, e.g. like this:
The mean body mass of all penguins is 4202 g.

Extra
Can you report the number of penguins and their body mass separately for the three penguin species?
Hint: Calculate the mean weight of the penguin species in a separate code chunk and save them in 3 variables. Then you can use these variables in the inline code.
2.3 Chunk options
Now we modify some of the code output using chunk options.
Start with the chunk that produces the figure:
Add a figure caption.
If you want, change the figure size using either fig.width and fig.height or out.width
Align the figure where you like to have it
Knit the document and look at the output.
Now think of some global chunk options that might make sense for your document. Add the ones that you like to have to the knitr options in the setup chunk.
You can for example think of things like:
Should the R code be shown in the document?
Should warnings and messages be printed into the document as well?

3 Change YAML header
In the last step, we will add some additional YAML metadata and document options to the document.
Also in this task, you can try out the options that you find most interesting. But I will give you some basic suggestions of what to try.
Knit often, to see the difference that the options make to the document.
Metadata
Add today’s date to the document
Add a subtitle
Document options
Today, we mostly worked with html_document output. So add some options for this document type to the YAML header. Be careful to respect the rules of indentation.
Options that might be interesting to try on your document:
df_print: set it to "kable" and see how the style of the table that you printed looks like
Add a table of contents. Explore the following options (start with those that seem most interesting to you):
toc
toc_depth
number_sections
toc_float: This option is only working for html output only

If you show your code, you can try different code highlighting themes using highlight option
Try a different theme, using the theme option (html only)
Values you can try are “flatly”, “journal” or “united”
Here you can find a list of other themes to try

Try code_folding: "hide" (html only) to hide code and make it available via a button


paper available here.↩︎

articles.title: Additional resources
articles.description: Below you can find a collection of helpful links to further online resources and a list of useful packages regarding the workshop topics.
articles.contents:
Contents
General
R packages

General
There are two books that I very much recommend as reference:
R Markdown: The definitive guide: Covers everything from getting started, to many different document types (html, pdf, word, xaringan presentations, websites, books, journal articles, …), to parameterized reports. You can just scroll through the table of contents of the book to see what you can do with rmarkdown and get inspiration.
R markdown cookbook: Covers the basics and different document types. Is more structured by docuemnt elements than by document types. Also here, you can scroll through the table of contents to see what is possible and how to do it.
A list of R Markdown books: This list contains the two above-mentioned books but also lists some other books about R Markdown that are freely available
R markdown cheat sheet: Handy as a reference while working
Comprehensive Markdown cheat sheet: Not exactly pandoc flavoured markdown but most of the things work the same. So this page is a good and comprehensive list of markdown elements that you can use to format your texts
R packages
In the table below, you can find a list of R packages with a short description and some links for further reading. The package selection is based on my personal experience and packages that I regularly use and like in combination with rmarkdown. The list is in no way complete. If you know a useful package that I missed, let me know and I can add it to the list.
